questions.text: An otherwise healthy 28-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 14-day history of painful red nodules on her legs associated with malaise and mild joint pains. She reports that the nodules were initially smaller and distinct but some have fused together over the past 3–4 days and now appear like bruises. There is no preceding history of fever, trauma, or insect bites. Her vital signs are within normal limits. A photograph of the tender lesions on her shins is shown. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Complete blood count and antistreptolysin O (ASO) titers are within the reference range. Erythrocyte sedimentation rate is 30 mm/h. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

One of the most common conditions associated with EN is streptococcal pharyngitis, which can be treated with oral amoxicillin. However, this patient had no preceding complaints of a sore throat and has a normal CBC and ASO titers, making a streptococcal infection unlikely. Oral amoxicillin may be indicated for the treatment of subcutaneous abscesses that manifest as tender nodules, like in this case scenario. The lesions in this patient evolved into bruise-like lesions, however, which is a typical manifestation of EN. In addition, patients with subcutaneous infections would have signs of systemic disease (e.g., fever) and neutrophilic leukocytosis.

B) INCORRECT:

Serum antinuclear antibodies (ANA) indicate the presence of circulating autoantibodies. Highly elevated ANA levels are an indication of an underlying autoimmune disease, such as systemic lupus erythematosus, rheumatoid arthritis, Sjögren syndrome, or systemic sclerosis. This patient's ESR is elevated and she has malaise and joint pain, which could be a sign of an underlying autoimmune disease. EN is nonspecific and can occasionally occur in patients with an underlying autoimmune disease. However, ANA are not part of the routine diagnostic workup of EN. A more common cause of EN should first be investigated and ruled out before looking at less common causes.

C) CORRECT:

EN is thought to be due to a delayed-type hypersensitivity reaction to various circulating immune complexes. Most cases of EN are idiopathic, but it can be a cutaneous manifestation of an underlying/preceding systemic disease, most commonly streptococcal pharyngitis or sarcoidosis. The primary workup of every patient with EN should therefore include evaluation of CBC and ASO titers, which are normal in this patient. The elevated ESR could be indicative of a systemic illness. The next step is to obtain an x-ray of the chest to evaluate for the presence of hilar lymphadenopathy, a sign of underlying sarcoidosis, which commonly affects young women, such as this patient.

Because EN can be associated with tuberculosis, testing for latent tuberculosis (e.g., tuberculin skin test or interferon-gamma release assay) is also indicated at the time of diagnosis. Other known triggers of EN include inflammatory bowel disease (EN is the most common cutaneous manifestation of Crohn disease), pregnancy, malignancy (e.g., lymphoma), and infections (e.g., coccidioidomycosis, brucellosis, psittacosis, and gastroenteritis secondary to Yersinia, Salmonella, and Campylobacter).
Image Description:

Chest x-ray (PA view)

The lungs have a pattern of innumerable small nodular opacities. The hila are enlarged and lobulated (red overlay) and the right paratracheal stripe is widened (green overlay).

Bilateral hilar and right mediastinal adenopathy is suggestive of sarcoidosis and is referred to as the “Garland triad” or “1-2-3 sign.”

D) INCORRECT:

Stool cultures are helpful in the diagnosis of gastrointestinal infections. Gastroenteritis secondary to Yersinia, Salmonella, and Campylobacter can cause EN. However, given the absence of diarrhea, nausea, or abdominal pain, this etiology is unlikely and, therefore, stool culture is not indicated.

E) INCORRECT:

EN is a clinical diagnosis. A biopsy of the lesion is indicated only if atypical features are seen, such as ulceration or location other than the shins. The characteristic histopathologic finding is a septal panniculitis without vasculitis. Because this patient presents with typical features of EN, (i.e., bilaterally symmetrical, multiple, tender, nonulcerated subcutaneous nodules/plaques on the shins), a biopsy is not indicated.

F) INCORRECT:

The lesions associated with EN usually resolve spontaneously within a few weeks. Intralesional steroid injections (e.g., with triamcinolone) are a treatment option for patients with severe pain despite treatment with NSAIDs.
questions.hint: This patient presents with spontaneous onset of tender, erythematous, subcutaneous nodules on both shins that developed into bruise-like plaques without ulceration. These features are characteristic of erythema nodosum (EN), an inflammation of the subcutaneous fat (i.e., panniculitis) that is commonly preceded by or associated with a prodrome of malaise, and arthralgia.

questions.text:
A 66-year-old woman presents for evaluation of tender red nodules on the anterior surface of both legs that developed a few days ago (figure). She has had no fever, chills, weight loss, dyspnea, or anorexia. She has a history of hilar adenopathy that was documented by chest radiograph several years ago and was stable on a repeat chest radiograph.
Which one of the following treatments is the most appropriate initial therapy for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

An antibiotic, such as levofloxacin, is not indicated in a patient who has no evidence of infection.

B) INCORRECT:

Other forms of immunosuppression, such as azathioprine or hydroxychloroquine, are indicated only when symptoms of sarcoidosis are uncontrolled by a systemic glucocorticoid or the disease advances despite treatment.

C) INCORRECT:

Other forms of immunosuppression, such as azathioprine or hydroxychloroquine, are indicated only when symptoms of sarcoidosis are uncontrolled by a systemic glucocorticoid or the disease advances despite treatment.

D) CORRECT:

Sarcoidosis can manifest as hilar adenopathy (on a chest radiograph) and skin lesions, such as erythema nodosum. Erythema nodosum is the characteristic lesion of acute sarcoidosis; its tenderness can be mitigated by treatment with a nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drug, such as ibuprofen.

Pulmonary sarcoidosis has four stages:
• Stage 1 (as in this case): bilateral hilar adenopathy
• Stage 2: bilateral hilar adenopathy and parenchymal infiltrates
• Stage 3: parenchymal infiltrates without adenopathy
• Stage 4: signs of fibrosis

Patients with sarcoidosis, even those with pulmonary involvement, do not necessarily require systemic glucocorticoid therapy, such as prednisone. Treatment with a systemic glucocorticoid is deferred unless organ function is abnormal or the patient develops pulmonary parenchymal infiltrates (stage 2 and higher). A decision to use a glucocorticoid demands consideration of its substantial adverse effects.

Key learning point: The recommended initial treatment of erythema nodosum should include nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drug therapy.

E) INCORRECT:

Patients with sarcoidosis, even those with pulmonary involvement, do not necessarily require systemic glucocorticoid therapy, such as prednisone. Treatment with a systemic glucocorticoid is deferred unless organ function is abnormal or the patient develops pulmonary parenchymal infiltrates (stage 2 and higher).

questions.text:
A 46-year-old man presents with discolored, tender spots over both lower extremities (figure). He has a 4-year history of ulcerative colitis that has been well controlled with mesalamine 2.4 grams daily for the past year. He reports adhering to his treatment but has 3 to 4 loose stools per day.
Which one of the following management approaches is most appropriate for this patient’s skin condition?

choices.text: Perform a biopsy of the rash
Initiate treatment for a flare of ulcerative colitis
Apply topical glucocorticoids to the rash

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Biopsy of the rash is not necessary when the diagnosis of erythema nodosum is apparent.

B) CORRECT:

Several extraintestinal manifestations of ulcerative colitis (UC) — including thromboembolism, episcleritis, erythema nodosum, and peripheral arthritis — parallel disease activity. The tender, red, smooth, and shiny nodules on this patient's lower extremities are characteristic of erythema nodosum. Although these nodules are usually found on the lower extremities, they can also occur elsewhere.

In a patient with UC who has erythema nodosum, systemic therapy to treat the UC flare will be needed to effectively treat the erythema nodosum. A colonoscopy can be considered to confirm the severity of the flare and help with medication choice (glucocorticoid vs. biologic agent).

Key learning point: The extraintestinal manifestations of ulcerative colitis that correlate with disease activity include the dermatologic condition known as erythema nodosum.

C) INCORRECT:

Erythema nodosum generally does not respond to topical glucocorticoids.

D) INCORRECT:

Increasing this patient’s mesalamine dose is unlikely to treat his erythema nodosum, given that his UC is not well treated with the mesalamine alone.

E) INCORRECT:

Ganciclovir can be used to treat colitis due to cytomegalovirus (CMV) infection, which can manifest as diarrhea, fever, and abdominal pain. CMV colitis can occur in patients with inflammatory bowel disease if they are significantly immunosuppressed from their medications. However, this patient’s only medication is mesalamine, which does not lead to immunosuppression significant enough to increase the risk of CMV colitis; thus, ganciclovir is not indicated.

questions.text:
An 18-year-old female college student presents with a one-week history of persistent fevers, generalized myalgias, arthralgias, and malaise. She also has a 2-day history of painful nodules on her shins. She recalls a recent sore throat that has resolved. She has had no prior trauma, nausea, or diarrhea.
Physical examination reveals a temperature of 38.1°C, mild cervical and submandibular lymphadenopathy, and tender subcutaneous nodules on the anterior shins of both legs (figure).
Which one of the following tests is most appropriate in this patient's workup?

choices.text: Obtain throat culture and antistreptolysin O titer
Obtain induced sputum samples for mycobacterial culture

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Although inflammatory bowel disease can be associated with erythema nodosum, colonoscopy would not be the first-line test in a patient without gastrointestinal symptoms.

B) CORRECT:

Erythema nodosum is a type of panniculitis, an inflammatory disorder in which the subcutaneous fat is the primary site of inflammation. It is characterized by tender nodules that appear red on pale skin or deep red to violaceous on skin of color. The nodules are usually found on the extensor aspects of the lower legs (anterior shins) but can also occur elsewhere. Patients may experience a prodrome of fevers, malaise, and arthralgias about 1 to 3 weeks before the onset of the nodules. Hyperpigmentation may persist after the nodules resolve. Erythema nodosum is thought to represent a hypersensitivity reaction to a systemic disease or to a drug; common culprits include oral contraceptives, sulfonamides, and penicillins. Although a trigger may be identified, up to 55% of cases are idiopathic. The most common identifiable trigger is a streptococcal infection, which accounts for up to 44% of cases in adults and 48% of cases in children. Workup should therefore include an evaluation for streptococcal infection. A deep-skin biopsy can confirm the diagnosis of erythema nodosum, but in most cases, the diagnosis is clinical and does not require biopsy.

Key learning point: The most common identifiable cause of erythema nodosum is a preceding streptococcal infection.

C) INCORRECT:

Although bacterial gastroenteritis can be associated with erythema nodosum, stool culture would not be the first-line test in a patient without gastrointestinal symptoms.

D) INCORRECT:

Certain pulmonary conditions, such as sarcoidosis, coccidioidomycosis, and histoplasmosis, are associated with erythema nodosum. In cases where there are symptoms suggestive of these conditions (e.g., chronic dyspnea or cough, sputum production, or hemoptysis), further evaluation with chest radiography or sputum testing may be indicated. However, in this case, the likelihood of these conditions is extremely low given the lack of both classic symptoms and reported risk factors.

E) INCORRECT:

Certain pulmonary conditions, including tuberculosis, are associated with erythema nodosum. In cases where there are symptoms suggestive of these conditions (e.g., chronic dyspnea or cough, sputum production, or hemoptysis), further evaluation with sputum testing may be indicated. However, in this case, the likelihood of these conditions is extremely low given the lack of both classic symptoms and reported risk factors.

questions.text:
A 32-year-old woman presents with a one-week history of tender skin lesions on her lower legs. During the interview, she notes a 2-year history of intermittent abdominal pain and diarrhea that has worsened acutely. She has been told that she has irritable bowel syndrome and has been treated with antispasmodics, but her symptoms have not improved. Her recent bowel movements have contained scant amounts of blood.
Her vital signs and cardiopulmonary examination are normal. Her abdomen has hyperactive bowel sounds and tenderness that is most prominent in the right lower quadrant; there is no rebound or guarding. Skin examination reveals tender erythematous plaques and nodules on her shins (figure).
Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Pyoderma gangrenosum is an autoimmune ulcerative process characterized by progressive cutaneous ulceration featuring an active, inflamed, undermined border with deeply necrotic centers.

B) INCORRECT:

Pancreatic panniculitis may manifest similarly to erythema nodosum, as tender red nodules on the legs; however, there is often an oily substance draining from the nodules, and the patient would have underlying pancreatitis or pancreatic malignancy. The history in this case does not suggest a pancreatic etiology.

C) INCORRECT:

Polyarteritis nodosa, a vasculitis of small to medium-sized arteries, may manifest as cutaneous nodules, but features of purpura or livedo reticularis will often be present, indicating a more active vascular injury pattern. Polyarteritis nodosa may be limited to the skin or associated with vasculitis of internal organs.

D) INCORRECT:

Sweet syndrome is a neutrophilic dermatosis characterized by “juicy” edematous red plaques or nodules, often in association with infections or acute myelogenous leukemia. It does not manifest as subcutaneous nodules.

E) CORRECT:

Erythema nodosum is a panniculitis characterized by tender erythematous to reddish-brown subcutaneous nodules on the anterior shins. Given the symptoms described in this case, this patient likely has inflammatory bowel disease-associated erythema nodosum.

Erythema nodosum is a reaction pattern that may also occur in association with other conditions, including sarcoidosis, infections, and lymphoma, or with particular medications. The most commonly reported infectious etiology is streptococcal infection, but erythema nodosum may also be seen with many other infections, including tuberculosis and other bacterial, fungal, and viral infections. Oral contraceptives are also rare causes of erythema nodosum.

Key learning point: Subcutaneous nodules on the shins of a patient with inflammatory bowel disease most likely represent erythema nodosum.

questions.text:
A 27-year-old woman presents with a 2-week history of tender, erythematous nodules on her shins and a persistent dry cough to the Outpatient Clinic. She reports mild fatigue and chest tightness when climbing stairs. She has no significant travel history. Examination reveals multiple raised, warm nodules on both lower legs. Basic laboratory tests, including CBC and electrolytes, are unremarkable.
Which of the following is the next best action in management?

choices.text: Punch biopsy of a leg nodule

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

The patient's presentation with tender nodules on the shins suggests erythema nodosum, often associated with sarcoidosis, especially when respiratory symptoms like a persistent dry cough are present. A chest radiograph is the initial imaging choice to confirm sarcoidosis, as it can reveal bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy, a classic finding. This imaging not only supports clinical suspicion by showing pulmonary involvement but also helps in staging the disease, guiding further management. Its noninvasive nature and availability make it the most appropriate next step in diagnosing suspected sarcoidosis.

Key learning point: In a patient presenting with erythema nodosum and respiratory symptoms, a chest X-ray is an important diagnostic step to evaluate for underlying conditions such as sarcoidosis.

B) INCORRECT:

Tuberculin skin testing detects prior exposure to Mycobacterium tuberculosis. However, the patient's lack of TB exposure history and absence of systemic TB signs make tuberculosis an unlikely cause. The symptoms align more with sarcoidosis, making chest imaging more appropriate.

C) INCORRECT:

A punch biopsy of erythema nodosum nodules shows nonspecific inflammation and does not identify the underlying systemic condition. Given the respiratory symptoms, chest imaging is more informative for diagnosing a systemic process like sarcoidosis.

D) INCORRECT:

High-dose glucocorticoid therapy is used in managing sarcoidosis but is not a diagnostic step. Initiating treatment without a confirmed diagnosis risks masking clinical and radiologic findings, potentially complicating the identification of the underlying condition.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents with a 5-day history of painful red nodules on both shins. She reports fever, joint pain in her ankles and knees, and malaise that began 1 week prior to the skin lesions. Physical examination findings are shown. What is the most appropriate management?

choices.text: Obtain tissue culture of the nodules
Order skin biopsy for histopathologic examination

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Tissue culture is not indicated for erythema nodosum because it is a sterile inflammatory condition caused by delayed hypersensitivity reaction, not an infectious process requiring culture.

B) CORRECT:

Correct -- Erythema nodosum is a clinical diagnosis based on the presence of characteristic painful subcutaneous nodules on the pretibial surfaces. Initial management consists of symptomatic treatment with nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs for anti-inflammatory effect, along with supportive measures including bed rest and leg elevation. Erythema nodosum is most commonly idiopathic, but underlying conditions (e.g., infections, autoimmune conditions, malignancy) should be considered in the diagnostic workup.

C) INCORRECT:

Empiric antibiotics are not indicated because erythema nodosum is a sterile inflammatory panniculitis. While an underlying infection may trigger the condition, the nodules themselves do not require antibiotic treatment.

D) INCORRECT:

Systemic corticosteroids are reserved for severe or refractory cases of erythema nodosum. Another management approach is more appropriate.

E) INCORRECT:

Skin biopsy is only indicated when the diagnosis of erythema nodosum is uncertain. This patient presents with bilateral pretibial nodules with systemic symptoms, which are characteristic of the condition.
